name: Letter from Clusius, Carolus to Lipsius, Justus, 1588-03-26

Diplomatic.text: Iusto Lipsio Carolus Clusius S[alutem] P[lurimam] D[icit]. Valde me afflixit adversa tua valetudo, mi Lipsi, vires autem te ex parte recepisse gaudeo atque ut te salvum et incolumem nobis conservet, Deum opt[imum] precor. De Smetiano thesauro recte factum, velim, quod libentissime fecissem, symbolam conferre potuissem. Habeo enim quae in his religionibus collegi quaepiam fideliter descripta, nam meis oculis plus fidere soleo quam alienis, praesertim in veterum inscriptionum exceptione. Non credas quam turpiter Lazius interdum sit lapsus. Quae in Hispanica peregrinatione collegeram, dedit M[arcus] Laurinus Smetio, at meum exemplar numquam restitutum, tametsi saepiuscule repetierim antequam huc accerserer. Ea forte suis locis in volumine distribuit Smetius. Si in animo habueritis appendicem aliquam aliquando addere ad opus quod nunc sub praelo est, quae habeo conferam ex animo. Et non dubito quin brevi editionem repetere cogatur typographus, adeo omnibus gratum futurum illum thesaurum scio. Dacicam peregrinationem suscipere me fatum non sinit: proximo enim Augusto Francofurtum ad Moenum cogito, ubi hiemem transigam Deo volente et forte reliquum quod superest vitae tempus. Multos iam menses ista Irene nostram spem alit, sed illa nimium dubia mihi videtur. Optare quidem, ut tu scribis, licet si non potiri. Illustri Pinello proximis litteris salutem a te dicam. Mercurialis familiaritatem nondum sum adeptus; Pinellum tamen orabo ut officium faciat. Si quid in Velleium Paterculum haberem, minime inviderem, mihi crede. Tu porro perge in utilissime coeptis. Nisi Dodonaeus iunior admodum sit immutatus, haud pol paternum sapit et plerumque Heroum filii noxae. Habeo aliquot eius epistolas, Patavio ad me datas, deus bone, quam ineptas! Obscurorum virorum epistolis adiici oportebat. Patri multas molestias creavit; is tamen, ut intelligo et gaudeo, paulo ante obitum reconciliatus est. Bene et feliciter vale, Clarissime Lipsi. Salutem dico nostro Raphelingio et N[obilissimo] V[iro] Douzae, facie necdum mihi noto. Viennae Austriacae, VII Kal[endas] April[es] M.D.XXCVIII. [Address:] Clarissimo Viro, D[omi]n[o] Iusto Lipsio, Professori nobilissimo in Academia Lugdunensi etc[etera] apud Batavos.

annotations.text: Hispanica peregrinatione: Clusius accompanied Jacobus Fugger on a journey through the north of Spain from May 1564 to May 1565. Early in June he was back in Antwerp.

Dacicam peregrinationem: In a lost letter from the end of 1587, Clusius must have informed Lipsius that he was planning a journey through Transylvania, to botanize and, presumably, at the same time also copying whatever inscriptions he might find.
Moenum: Clusius left Vienna definitively in the second half of August 1588 and arrived in Frankfurt in the first days of September.

annotations.text: Velleium Paterculum: Apparently, Lipsius must have asked Clusius in a lost letter whether he had a manuscript or an early edition of the Roman historiographer Velleius Paterculus. He was planning an annotated edition of his work, which appeared in January 1591.
Dodonaeus iunior: Rembert Dodoens Jr, the only son of Rembert Sr.

annotations.text: Heroum ... noxae: Cf. Erasmus, Adagia, 1, 6, 32, quoting several authors from Antiquity.
huc: In 1573 Emperor Maximilian II had invited Clusius to Vienna to lay out a medicinal garden.
typographus: The work was printed by Franciscus Raphelengius.

annotations.text: Obscurorum ... epistolis: A satirical answer to the Epistolae clarorum virorum, published by Jihann Reuchlin in 1514. The Epistolae obscurorum virorum are part of the clash between Reuchlin and the theologians of the university of Cologne, mainly the Dominican Jacob van Hoogstraeten.
Smetiano thesauro: Lipsius had informed Clusius that he had prepared Martinus Smetius’s Inscriptiones antiquae for the printer.
Lazius: Wolfgang Lazius, cf. ILE III, 88 01 14 LE, 24
